hope.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to want something to happen or be true and to believe that it is possible or likely
hope.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Liam decided to ignore the warning and just hope for the best (=hope that a situation will end well when there is a risk of things going wrong).
I rang my parents, hoping against hope (=hoping for something that is very unlikely to happen or be true) that they hadn’t left yet.
We hope that more women will decide to join the course.
I do hope everything goes well.
It was hoped that the job would be filled by a local person.
Let’s just hope someone finds her bag.
I hope to God I haven’t left the car window open.
Joan’s hoping to study law at Harvard.
We were hoping for good weather.
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: GRAMMAR: Patterns with hope
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: We’re hoping to get tickets to the concert
I hope to see you soon
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: I hope that the rain stops soon
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: You hope that something will happen
I hope that the weather will be fine
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].items[3]: You hoped that something would happen
She hoped that the weather would be fine
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].items[4]: You hoped that something might happen
I was hoping that you might come
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].items[5]: You hope that someone can do something
I hope that I can pass my exam
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].items[6]: You hoped that someone could do something
She hoped that she could pass her exam
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].items[7]: In more formal English, you say it is hoped that something will happen
It is hoped that the study will provide some useful information
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].items[8]: In all the above patterns, ‘that’ is often omitted, especially in spoken English
I hope the rain stops soon
She hoped the weather would be fine
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].items[9]: Hope is often used in the progressive
I’m hoping to meet him some day
hope.translation[0].note_box[0].items[10: Hope is used in the phrases I hope so and I hope not, often to give a short answer
‘Will he be here soon?’ ‘I hope so’
‘Do you think it will rain?’ ‘I hope not!’
hope.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a feeling of wanting something to happen or be true and believing that it is possible or likely
hope.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: When I first arrived in New York, I was full of hope for the future.
The president has expressed the hope that relations will improve.
hopes for an end to the fighting
Rita has hopes of studying to be a nurse.
Should they hang on in the hope that the shares will go up in value?
Shoppers flocked to the sales in the hope of finding a bargain.
in the hope of doing something
hope.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: something that you hope will happen
hope.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: She told him all her secret hopes and fears.
My hope is that by next summer I’ll have saved enough money to go travelling.
hope.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a chance of succeeding or of something good happening
not a hope! spoken (=used to say that there is no chance of something happening)
hope.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: They don’t have a hope in hell of winning.
not a hope in hell (of doing something)
‘Your dad might lend you the car.’ ‘Some hope!’
It was the rush hour, and there was no hope of getting a seat.
It was a desperate plan, with little hope of success.
There’s still a faint hope  (=a very small chance) that the two sides will reach an agreement.
hope.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: have hope
The situation looked bad, but we still had hope that things would get better soon.
give/offer hope
The research has given hope to thousands of sufferers of the disease.
lose/give up/abandon hope
After so long without any word from David, Margaret was starting to lose hope.
raise somebody’s hopes
I don't want to raise your hopes too much.
Don’t build your hopes up, Julie. You’ll only get hurt.
hold out hope
Negotiators did not hold out much hope of a peaceful solution.
pin your hopes on something
After a difficult year, the company is pinning its hopes on its new range of products.
cling to the hope that
They clung to the hope that one day a cure would be found.
dash/shatter somebody’s hopes
The ending of the talks has dashed any hopes of peace.
hopes are fading
Hopes are fading that rescuers will find any more survivors.
hope lies in/with something
Our real hope lies with a vaccine.
be full of hope
His voice sounded full of hope.
a glimmer/ray of hope
The new treatment gives patients a glimmer of hope.
somebody’s hopes and dreams
We talked about all our hopes and dreams for the future.
somebody’s hopes and fears
The crew members have different hopes and fears about the trip.
it is our fervent hope that
It is our fervent hope that change is coming.
hope springs eternal
It is unlikely these diets will work, but hope springs eternal.
a symbol/beacon of hope
Mandela was a symbol of hope for his whole country.
false hope
We don't want to give people false hopes.
a vain/forlorn hope
He traveled south in the vain hope of finding work.
somebody's only/one hope
My only hope is that someone may have handed in the keys to the police.
